title: 109_s2636
content: The "Oil Company Accountability Act" may be cited as the short title. It includes an Energy Tax Rebate under a new section 6430 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Individuals will receive a $500 payment against the tax imposed for the 2006 taxable year. The Secretary will remit the payment within 30 days of the enactment. Certain individuals, estates, trusts, and nonresident aliens are not eligible for this payment. Section 151 allows the $500 payment for the 2006 taxable year to certain individuals, estates, trusts, and nonresident aliens. A conforming amendment is made to Section 1324(b)(2) of title 31, and a clerical amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by this section regarding energy tax rebate shall take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act. Additionally, there is a revaluation of LIFO inventories of large integrated oil companies. The taxpayer, if an applicable integrated oil company for its last taxable year ending in 2005, must increase the value of historic LIFO inventories of oil, gas, or petroleum products by a layer adjustment amount. This results in a decrease in the cost of goods sold for that year. If the increases exceed the cost of goods sold, the gross income is increased by the excess amount. The layer adjustment amount is defined for this purpose. The layer adjustment amount, defined as $18.75 multiplied by the number of barrels of crude oil or barrel-of-oil equivalents in a historic LIFO layer, is not considered a change in accounting method. No change in accounting method for adjustment required by this section. No addition to tax under section 6655 for underpayments due to this section. Applicable integrated oil company defined as one with daily worldwide crude oil production of at least 500,000 barrels. An applicable integrated oil company is defined as one with daily worldwide crude oil production of at least 500,000 barrels and gross receipts exceeding $1,000,000,000 for the last taxable year ending in 2005. MODIFICATIONS OF FOREIGN TAX CREDIT RULES FOR LARGE INTEGRATED OIL COMPANIES. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include special rules for large integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers. Any amount paid to a foreign country or possession of the United States by such companies will not be considered a tax under certain conditions. The Internal Revenue Code includes special rules for large integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers. Any amount paid to a foreign country or possession of the United States by such companies will not be considered a tax under certain conditions. The rules specify that the possession does not impose a generally applicable income tax, and the amount paid should not exceed what would be paid under the applicable income tax of the country or possession. The term 'dual capacity taxpayer' refers to a person subject to a levy of a foreign country or possession, who receives a specific economic benefit from that country. 'Generally applicable income tax' is defined as an income tax generally imposed under the laws of a country. The term 'income tax' refers to a tax imposed by a foreign country on income from business activities within that country, with exceptions for certain individuals. A 'large integrated oil company' is defined as an integrated oil company meeting specific criteria for a taxable year. The term 'large integrated oil company' is defined as an integrated oil company with gross receipts exceeding $1,000,000,000 and an average daily worldwide production of at least 500,000 barrels of crude oil for a taxable year. The amendments made by this section apply to taxes paid or accrued in taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act, except where contrary to any treaty obligation of the United States.
